prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.

The Russian foreign ministry has stated that the charges against the soldier are unrelated to political or espionage activities, but rather involve a "common criminal offense".

The 34-year-old soldier, who was not on official duty at the time, was detained on May 2 in Vladivostok, a city located in Russia's Far Eastern region.

The soldier, identified as Sgt Black, was in the process of transferring duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in Texas, USA, when he decided to travel to Vladivostok for personal reasons, passing through China en route.

According to Russian media reports, Sgt Black was visiting a woman he was romantically involved with. His mother, Melody Jones, has confirmed to CBS that her son was in Russia to visit his girlfriend.

When asked about her message to the Russian authorities, Melody Jones pleaded with them not to harm her son.

Sgt Black enlisted in the army in 2008 and has served in Iraq and Afghanistan. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea, at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

The soldier did not obtain official clearance for his travel to China and Russia, and the US Department of Defense did not authorize his trip. There is no indication that he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on May 3 that Sgt Black had been arrested the previous day on charges of stealing personal property.

He is currently being held at a pre-trial detention facility, awaiting his next court hearing.

The US Army has notified Sgt Black's family and the US Department of State is providing consular support to him in Russia.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby has stated that the US is aware of Sgt Black's case, as well as other matters related to Russia, but could not provide further details.

The sergeant, a 14-year veteran with experience in Iraq and Afghanistan, was detained on May 2 in Vladivostok, Russia, after making an unscheduled stop to visit his girlfriend while traveling from South Korea to Texas, USA. At the time, he lacked the necessary permits to pass through China and Russia.

The sergeant, recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea, at Camp Humphreys in South Korea, was in the process of relocating to Texas from South Korea when he took the unauthorized detour, traveling through China without proper clearance.

On May 3, the Russian interior ministry notified the US embassy in Moscow that the sergeant had been arrested the previous day on suspicion of theft.

The sergeant is currently being held in a pre-trial facility, awaiting his next court appearance. His family has been informed by the US Army, and the US Department of State is providing consular assistance to him in Russia.

The National Security Council is aware of the sergeant's case, as well as other Russia-related matters, but cannot provide further information at this time.

It's worth noting that Russia is currently holding two other American citizens: Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, who has been detained since March 2023 on suspicion of espionage, and former US Marine Paul Whelan, who was convicted of spying in 2020 and sentenced to 16 years in prison. Both men deny any wrongdoing, and the US government has dismissed the charges against them as unfounded.
